Situation1: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: While traveling, only a small vendor known to be kosher-certified is within reach for the next meal.
Story:
I sat in the back row of the conference room, my notepad open, listening intently as the speaker outlined the latest prescription guidelines. As a pharmacist, I knew how crucial it was to stay updated—patients depended on me for safe, accurate advice. The workshop ran longer than expected, and by the time it ended, my stomach was growling. I glanced at my watch; I had just enough time to grab a quick meal before my next shift. 

But as I stepped outside, I realized the only nearby food option was a small vendor I recognized as kosher-certified. The line was long, and I worried I might be late. The other attendees were heading to a trendy café across the street, chatting about the session, eager to continue networking. I felt the pull—joining them would help me build professional relationships, maybe even learn more. But I couldn’t eat there; nothing was kosher. 

Standing on the sidewalk, I felt the tension knot in my chest. My commitment to my faith and my dedication to my profession were suddenly at odds, and I didn’t know which expectation I could afford to let down.
